awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Medium: Collaborative: Safety and Security for Targets of Digital Violence
awd_abstract_narration:
This research has a foundational, multi-disciplinary research agenda that examines the role of technology in intimate partner violence and investigates the development of new tools, techniques, and theories to combat technology-enabled abuse. The work is important because digital technologies play an increasingly prominent role in domestic violence, stalking, and surveillance by abusive partners and others known to the victim. The research builds on prior work detailing the ways in which abusers exploit technology to monitor, harass, track, and control victims. This kind of abuse challenges common approaches to computer security: although the attacks that abusers employ are often technically unsophisticated, the social and relational contexts in which attacks occur make them difficult to prevent. 

The proposed work weaves together research activities including building measurement platforms for making sense of abuser communities that are found online, designing tools for detecting spyware or apps usable as spyware on victim devices, developing a theory of adversary-aware human computer interaction that will guide user interface design in the face of adversaries that have a victim's login credentials, analyzing the efficacy of general consumer privacy legislation for abuse contexts, and seeking out pragmatic law and policy recommendations. The research makes the safety of (potential) victims paramount, which is facilitated by working closely with stakeholder organizations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project's major goals concern technology abuse in intimate partner violence (IPV). IPV is a widespread social will, with one third of all women and one sixth of all men reporting experiencing harms at some point in their life. In prior work, we and other researchers had documented the damaging ways technology has been used as a lever for coercive control by partners. This project's major goals were to (1) study online resources useful to abusers, (2) develop countermeasures against IPV spyware, (3) characterize and explore the UI-bound  threat model, (4) investigate legal aspects of IPV tech abuse, and (5) iterate on clinical approaches to intervention design. 


The project made significant progress towards improving outcomes for survivors of tech abuse in IPV. In terms of online studies, we pioneered new techniques for analyzing public online forums to learn about abuse tactics and develop a model for understanding how partners escalate to tech abuse. Many subsequent projects by our groups and others have used similar techniques. We worked closely with companies from the antivirus industry to understand more deeply the ecosystem of "creepware" --- apps useful for harassment, monitoring, or other abuse --- as well as improve customer service training practices for those seeking assistance with IPV tech abuse. We explored the UI-bound threat model that we defined in prior work, in particular in the context of account security, a frequent issue faced by survivors whose partners have compromised their accounts, as well as in financial technologies exploited by abusive partners to cause financial harms. We advocated for new state and federal laws, and as discussed below, helped pass survivor safety bills. Finally, we have developed a new area of scientific research: the design, deployment, and refinement of trauma-informed clinical tech abuse interventions. For example, we developed and successfully switched to remote consultations with IPV survivors, which increased accessibility while having to carefully navigate the safety tensions in communicating about technology abuse using potentially unsafe phones or other devices. We also designed and deployed a long-term care model for IPV tech abuse clinics, which is now still in use by our clinic, the Clinic to End Tech Abuse (CETA).


Our project has had a significant impact on the research field of technology abuse. We introduced a new framework for trauma-informed computing, and wrote two systemization papers about online hate and harassment and how to perform safer research with at-risk user populations. A new community of researchers now investigate interpersonal tech abuse, and reference our works frequently. We published 19 research articles, including many that received awards. 


In addition to the intellectual merits that advanced our field, this work has had many broader impacts. The work directly informed and improved CETA's operations, which now serves hundreds of IPV survivors per year to help them navigate technology abuse. It informed advocacy for systemic change, such as helping pass the federal Safe Connections Act of 2022 which ensured survivors can disconnect their cellular plans from their abusers. The work has led to many improvements to our technology, with companies adopting our suggestions for changes that help mitigate tech abuse.
